name.text: Evaluating Square Roots of Complex Numbers in Rectangular and Polar Form

questiontext.text:
Evaluate \( \displaystyle \sqrt{z}\) given that \(z={@z_real@} + {@z_imag@}i\).

Note:

  1. Give all the roots!

  2. You might want to write \(z\) in polar form first, with your solution in \(\pi\) radians, or in the form \(\displaystyle z=re^{i\theta}\) to simplify the calculations.

Possible values for \(\sqrt{z}:\)

\(\sqrt{z}= \) [[input:ans4]] or \(\sqrt{z}= \) [[input:ans5]]

\(\quad\) [[validation:ans4]] \(\quad \) [[validation:ans5]]

[[feedback:prt4]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked solution

Given \( \displaystyle z={@z_real@} + {@z_imag@}i\), let's express \(z\) in polar form:

  1. Magnitude (\(r\)) of \(z\):

    \(\displaystyle r = \sqrt{({@z_real@} )^2 + ({@z_imag@})^2} = \sqrt{{@z_real^2@} + {@z_imag^2@}} = \sqrt{{@z_real^2+ z_imag^2@}} = {@ta1@} \)

  2. Argument (\(\theta\)) of \(z\):

    \( \displaystyle \theta = \arctan\left(\frac{\text{Im}(z)}{\text{Re}(z)}\right) = \arctan\left(\frac{{@z_imag@}}{{@z_real@}}\right) \) \(\displaystyle \theta= {@arg@} \approx {@decimalplaces(arg,2)@}\)

  3. Now, \(z\) in polar form becomes:

    \(\displaystyle z = re^{i\theta} = {@radius@}e^{{@arg@}i} ={@ta3@}\)

  4. Expressing the square root of \(z\) in polar form:

    \(\displaystyle \sqrt{z} = \sqrt{ {@radius@}}e^{{@arg@}i}=\sqrt{{@ta3@}} \)

    Now, for possible values of \(\displaystyle \sqrt{z} ,\) we consider the fact that the square root function introduces a \( \pm \) sign:

    \(\displaystyle \sqrt{z} = {@ta4@} \) or

    \(\displaystyle \sqrt{z} = {@ta5@} \)
